instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1534: What is A1534? A1534 is a model number for a 12 inch size Macbook  from years 2015, 2016 with EMC 2746, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00045, 820-00244..
definitions.820-00687: What is 820-00687? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H? This is the input from the USB-C charger or the battery that is the input voltage for the chip responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H. It can be missing when capacitors on this line are shorted to ground, or when the diode in front of it leading to the chip that creates PP3V3_G3H is blown. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.820-00244: What is 820-00244? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Hello,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A that has no power. It pulls 19.5V from ampmeter, but 0Amp.

I have 8.6V on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, but <SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL> is 20V, Is that normal value?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Voltages look good.
You should check voltage on all big coils.

Any history available?
At least <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> appears?

Be aware, like all <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> boards, CPU will fail soon; if is not dead already...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Hi,
No history available. The client said that it stoped working.

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.3V

L7430 = 3.3V
L7410 = 0V
L7230 = 0V
L7210 = 0V

L7670 = 0V

L7030 = 0.53V
L9000 = 0V
L7960 = 0V
L8410 = 0.12V

L7900 = 0V
L8050 = 0V
L8000 = 0V
L7290 = 0V

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Use <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> schematic; original not available.

You can't get L7430 voltage.
Please, post accurate information.

"<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.3V"
Did you check it at L7690?

Check if <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> comes high.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
You're right. Sorry.

I have confused it with the L7690 that has 3.3V
L7430  has 0V.

<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> has 0V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
HI,

<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>  = 3.3V

PCH's RTC
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> =3.0V
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> = 2.7V
<SIGNAL>PCH_RTCRST_L</SIGNAL> = 3.0V

Hi couldn't find  <SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL>. Where can i find it?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL>  is not used anymore.

<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is there?
